thread.title: Feds shut 'failed' Longview bank, Hometown National
thread.title_full: Feds shut 'failed' Longview bank, Hometown National | OregonLive.com

author: Mike Rogoway | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Feds shut 'failed' Longview bank, Hometown National
text:
A federal agency shut down Hometown National Bank in Longview, Washington, on Friday afternoon.
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said clients' deposits will move to another Longview institution, Twin City Bank, and Hometown's only branch will become a Twin City bank.
Deposits continue to insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, according to the agencies, which asked the Hometown clients' continue using their existing branch in the near future.
The agencies did not explain why they are shuttering Hometown National, but said the bank had $4.9 million in assets and $4.7 million in deposits. Twin City Bank has committed to buy $3.8 million of Hometown's assets, according to the FDIC, which estimated the cost to its deposit insurance fund is $1.6 million.
Several Northwest banks followed during the financial crisis that spawned the Great Recession, when a number of smaller banks – and a few large ones – were consumed by bad loans underwritten with questionable lending standards.
But the pace of closure has eased considerably as the economy has improved. Hometown is the eighth FDIC-insured bank to close this year, and the first in Washington since Westside Community Bank in University Place closed in January 2013.
-- Mike Rogoway
